Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: High Performance Sense and Avoid
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to develop and provide novel computation capabilities to the marketplace that mimic and apply the way our brain computes beyond deep learning systems and much closer to how the brain actually operates. Although
the technology is initially targeted for the commercial drone market, the technology can be applied to consumer and hobbyist drone market, self-driving cars and advanced driver assistance systems, autonomous navigation and guiding systems with obstacle avoidance for
robots, ballistics tracking and counter-drone capabilities for military and defense, and surveillance and counter-drone for public safety and security. This project has the potential to revolutionize robotic and machine vision by providing capabilities that simply do not exist today.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project investigates novel ways, algorithms and software implementations that leverage expertise in natural vision systems, deep learning and machine learning to make use of electro-optical sensors, which
respond in new ways to form the basis of an Airborne Based Sense and Avoid (ABSAA) system. It leverages the benefits of bio-inspired computation, and investigates how to combine information from multiple sensors in a common representation. The project will study novel ways to achieve robust detection, segmentation, clustering, discrimination and classification with these novel sensors. It will also extend methods and algorithms for state estimation, tracking and prediction in the inherent sensor representation. The project will also address the real-time constraints and will attempt to leverage recent hardware implementations, which can provide a complete embedded system for ABSAA system that is low SWaP (size, weight and power) and in the long run, low cost as well because it has the potential to benefit from economy of scale. The theoretical and algorithmic advances generated by the project have the potential to affect
machine and robotic vision well beyond the project focused application to ABSAA.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Qelzal, under this NSF Phase I Award, has further developed Qelsafe, a unique Aircraft and Obstacle Avoidance System for commercial drones (UAVs - unmanned aerial vehicles) by leveraging novel vision sensors and processing technologies. Qelsafe's objective is to detect and avoid all types of obstacles and low flying aircraft, keeping drones and aircraft safe while allowing the drones to roam free beyond line of sight. Revenue will be generated by selling and, later, licensing Qelsafe to our customers, manufacturers (OEMs) of drones, flight controllers (autopilots) and drone operating system platforms, providing them with competitive differentiation. The Qelsafe Air1 kit includes sensors, processing hardware, and software of advanced algorithms, enabling a drone to see all around itself to detect aircraft and take evasive action.

During Phase I, Qelzal addressed the technical difficulties to achieve an Airborne Based Sense and Avoid (ABSAA) system. Major activities have included: Developing algorithms and their software implementation to perform the sensing part of the ABSAA, detecting aircraft at distance and track the aircraft once it is detected, provide tracking results to the onboard flight controller, implement the avoidance maneuver of the ABSAA by developing basic avoidance capabilities internally for testing. Qelzal tested the algorithms for avoidance as much as possible first in computer simulations then they were integrated and tested in drone experiments.

Qelzal designed the ABSAA product and determined its technical feasibility. Its integration onto drone platforms including the communications with the flight controller were determined, implemented and tested. Different design implementations were presented for multicopters and fixed wings drone platforms with a focus on providing a full 360 deg aircraft detection around the drone.

In Phase I, Qelzal demonstrated aircraft anticollision flash detection capabilities for distance up to 3 km. Qelzal’s vision sensor and an embedded computer was installed below a small commercial drone for testing. With the drone in flight, Qelzal demonstrated the ability to detect the flashes even in bright sunlight and while the drone was being tossed around in high gusty winds. Qelzal also demonstrated simultaneous and separate detection and tracking of an aircraft anticollision and microwave antenna flashing lights in bright desert sunlight. The antenna was located 3.35 km away and the aircraft anticollision light was moved up to 2.9 km away. In further experiments, Qelzal expects to demonstrate the detection ability to extend beyond 3 km.

Our results demonstrated that Qelzal’s unique system to detect flashes can be combined with motion estimation and tracking to better track aircraft equipped with flashing lights during day or night. It also demonstrated the ability to track with the same system flying objects habitually not equipped with anticollision flashing lights, such as paragliders and balloons during the day. Qelzal demonstrated multiple object tracking with a series of cars and aircraft, which were tracked simultaneously using real-time clustering and tracking algorithms.

During Phase I, Qelzal has developed designs for unique systems that increase their performance by orders of magnitude. Given preliminary data, Qelzal's systems have the possibility to passively detect (in contrast to active radar, lidar), identify, classify, and track multiple aircraft and/or small Unmanned Aerial Systems (sUAS) at distances, respectively beyond the current 3 km detection range for aircraft and reaching 1 km for sUAS. The system is expected in Phase II to be capable of generating and processing very detailed visual representations of target(s) and with lower bandwidth than conventional camera technology.  

The software was proprietary C++ code, which ran the whole processing pipeline in real-time on the drone mounted embedded computer, a 2014 octa-core ARM-based microprocessor developed to run on tablets. Low overall CPU usage (< 55%)  leaves room for further processing on this already 3-year old technology. Maximum main CPU power consumption as recorded by the internal power monitoring was only 5.7 watts.

Qelzal presented its Qelsafe AIR1 prototype system and its real-time capabilities on embedded computer at InterDrone 2017 a well attended international drone conference in Las Vegas last September.  Qelsafe AIR1 received a lot of attention from potential clients, regulatory agency (FAA), investors, as well as competing systems. Competing systems for sense & avoid in the drone market using different modalities such as radar and lidar that we know of have asked us to work with them on sensor fusion integration with their system. Qelzal has planned from the beginning to integrate sensor fusion into its unique vision processing pipeline to provide a robust and reliable sense & avoid system for the widest range of commercial drone flying conditions.  Qelzal has welcomed the partnership opportunities and has been moving forward with multiple partners.

In conclusion, Qelzal demonstrated in Phase I the technical and economical feasibility of developing a commercially viable Airborne Based Sense and Avoid (ABSAA) system in Phase II  that has low size, weight, power (SWaP) and cost for the commercial drone industry.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/01/2017
Modified by: Olivier Coenen
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Qelzal, under this NSF Phase I Award, has further developed Qelsafe, a unique Aircraft and Obstacle Avoidance System for commercial drones (UAVs - unmanned aerial vehicles) by leveraging novel vision sensors and processing technologies. Qelsafe's objective is to detect and avoid all types of obstacles and low flying aircraft, keeping drones and aircraft safe while allowing the drones to roam free beyond line of sight. Revenue will be generated by selling and, later, licensing Qelsafe to our customers, manufacturers (OEMs) of drones, flight controllers (autopilots) and drone operating system platforms, providing them with competitive differentiation. The Qelsafe Air1 kit includes sensors, processing hardware, and software of advanced algorithms, enabling a drone to see all around itself to detect aircraft and take evasive action. During Phase I, Qelzal addressed the technical difficulties to achieve an Airborne Based Sense and Avoid (ABSAA) system. Major activities have included: Developing algorithms and their software implementation to perform the sensing part of the ABSAA, detecting aircraft at distance and track the aircraft once it is detected, provide tracking results to the onboard flight controller, implement the avoidance maneuver of the ABSAA by developing basic avoidance capabilities internally for testing. Different design implementations were presented for multicopters and fixed wings drone platforms with a focus on providing a full 360 deg aircraft detection around the drone. In Phase I, Qelzal demonstrated aircraft anticollision flash detection capabilities for distance up to 3 km. Qelzal?s vision sensor and an embedded computer was installed below a small commercial drone for testing. With the drone in flight, Qelzal demonstrated the ability to detect the flashes even in bright sunlight and while the drone was being tossed around in high gusty winds. Qelzal also demonstrated simultaneous and separate detection and tracking of an aircraft anticollision and microwave antenna flashing lights in bright desert sunlight. The antenna was located 3.35 km away and the aircraft anticollision light was moved up to 2.9 km away. In further experiments, Qelzal expects to demonstrate the detection ability to extend beyond 3 km. Our results demonstrated that Qelzal?s unique system to detect flashes can be combined with motion estimation and tracking to better track aircraft equipped with flashing lights during day or night. It also demonstrated the ability to track with the same system flying objects habitually not equipped with anticollision flashing lights, such as paragliders and balloons during the day. Qelzal demonstrated multiple object tracking with a series of cars and aircraft, which were tracked simultaneously using real-time clustering and tracking algorithms. During Phase I, Qelzal has developed designs for unique systems that increase their performance by orders of magnitude. Given preliminary data, Qelzal's systems have the possibility to passively detect (in contrast to active radar, lidar), identify, classify, and track multiple aircraft and/or small Unmanned Aerial Systems (sUAS) at distances, respectively beyond the current 3 km detection range for aircraft and reaching 1 km for sUAS. The system is expected in Phase II to be capable of generating and processing very detailed visual representations of target(s) and with lower bandwidth than conventional camera technology. The software was proprietary C++ code, which ran the whole processing pipeline in real-time on the drone mounted embedded computer, a 2014 octa-core ARM-based microprocessor developed to run on tablets. Low overall CPU usage (< 55%) leaves room for further processing on this already 3-year old technology. Maximum main CPU power consumption as recorded by the internal power monitoring was only 5.7 watts. Qelzal presented its Qelsafe AIR1 prototype system and its real-time capabilities on embedded computer at InterDrone 2017 a well attended international drone conference in Las Vegas last September. Qelsafe AIR1 received a lot of attention from potential clients, regulatory agency (FAA), investors, as well as competing systems. Competing systems for sense & avoid in the drone market using different modalities such as radar and lidar that we know of have asked us to work with them on sensor fusion integration with their system. Qelzal has planned from the beginning to integrate sensor fusion into its unique vision processing pipeline to provide a robust and reliable sense & avoid system for the widest range of commercial drone flying conditions. Qelzal has welcomed the partnership opportunities and has been moving forward with multiple partners. In conclusion, Qelzal demonstrated in Phase I the technical and economical feasibility of developing a commercially viable Airborne Based Sense and Avoid (ABSAA) system in Phase II that has low size, weight, power (SWaP) and cost for the commercial drone industry.
